Fig. 1 (a) Optimised structures and total energy of pure Ag(1 1 1), 1L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1), 2L- Cu1Ag(1 1 1) and 3L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) alloys. 1,2,3L-M1Ag(1 1 1) represents an alloy system with a single M atom-doped on the surface (1L), subsurface (2L) and third layers (3L) of the pure Ag(1 1 1) surface. Blue and orange balls represent Ag and Cu atoms, respectively. (b) Segregation energy and (c) mixing energy of the 1L- and 2L- M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys. (d) Mulliken charge of alloying atoms M in the 1L- and 2L- M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys. The red dash line indicates the Mulliken charge (−0.029) of surface Ag atoms on pure Ag(1 1 1) surface. (e) Mulliken charge of surface Ag atoms in the 1L- and 2L- M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys. Compared with the Mulliken charge of surface Ag atoms on the pure Ag(1 1 1) surface, 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit a charge transfer from surface Ag to M, thus endowing the single M atom an anionic nature. Fig. 2 Calculated partial density of state (PDOS) of dilute nanoalloys with 2L-M1Ag structure for (a) 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) and Ag(1 1 1), (b) bulk Cu(1 1 1) and the d electron orbital of single Cu atom; (c) 2L-Ni1Ag(1 1 1) and Ag(1 1 1), (d) bulk Ni(1 1 1) and the d electron orbital of single Ni atom; (e) 2L-Zn1Ag(1 1 1) and Ag(1 1 1), (f) bulk Zn(1 1 1) and the d electron orbital of single Zn atom; (g) 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and Ag(1 1 1), (h) bulk Mn(1 1 1) and the d electron orbital of single Mn subsurface atom. The Fermi level is located at 0 eV. Fig. 3 Free-energy diagrams for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at different electrode potentials (U) on (a) 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1), (b) 2L-Ni1Ag(1 1 1), (c) 2L-Zn1Ag(1 1 1) and (d) 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy systems. Fig. 4 (a) Free-energy diagrams for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) alloys at different electrode potentials of U. (b) Free-energy diagrams for ORR on Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and Pt(1 1 1) alloys at U = 0 V. (c) Calculated partial density of state (PDOS) of Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) alloys. ε d (eV) is the d band centre of these alloys. (d) Calculated PDOS of 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) alloy, single Cu and Mn atom in 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) alloy, bulk Cu(1 1 1) and bulk Mn(1 1 1) alloy. Fig. 5 (a) High-resolution TEM, (b) SAED image, (c) EDS image and (d) EDX mapping of elemental distributions for Ag, Cu and Mn of the Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalyst. Fig. 6 (a) High-resolution TEM, (b) SAED image, (c) EDS image and (d) EDX mapping of elemental distributions for Ag, Cu and Mn of the DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalyst. Fig. 7 Rotation-rate-dependent current–potential of the (a) Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and (c) DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalyst. KouteckyeLevich plots for (b) Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and (d) DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalyst at different potentials. Fig. 8 Comparison of ORR activities of pure Ag, Cu25Ag75 and Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75, DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and commercial Pt/C catalysts: (a) ORR polarization curves recorded in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution with a rotation rate of 1600 rpm. (b) Specific activities at 0.8 V vs. RHE. (c) Tafel plots of pure Ag, Cu25Ag75 and Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75, DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and Pt/C catalysts. Graphical abstract The density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experiments are combined, and we find that the M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit high stability when M is on the subsurface of the Ag(1 1 1) facet. The overpotential of as-prepared CuMnAg nanoalloy is close to the predicted overpotential and that of the Pt/C catalyst. To address the sluggish kinetics of the electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), we consider a family of silver-based dilute nanoalloys by alloying the Ag(1 1 1) with one 3d transition metal atom M (M = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) as ORR catalysts in alkaline media. The M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit higher stability when M is on the subsurface (2L-M1Ag(1 1 1)) than when M is on the surface (1L-M1Ag(1 1 1)) of the Ag(1 1 1) facet as observed from surface segregation and mixing energies, and this subsurface stability is attributed to the relative positive charge transfer of surface Ag atoms as revealed from atomic charge analysis. Thus, 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) catalysts are further investigated for their electronic structure and ORR activities. Particularly, 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Ni1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Zn1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit a free-atom-like d state, and 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit an ORR overpotential of 0.459 and 0.468 V, respectively. For the first time, the ternary 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) is theoretically predicted with an overpotential of 0.450 V. Motivated by this prediction, we prepare a ternary CuMnAg nanoalloy by using the pulse laser deposition method. These ternary CuMnAg and dealloyed DE-CuMnAg catalysts exhibit an ORR overpotential of 0.50 and 0.47 V that is close to the predicted overpotential and that of a commercial Pt/C catalyst. Keywords Dilute nanoalloys Density functional theory Structural stability Oxygen reduction reaction Free energy diagram 1 Introduction Alkaline fuel cells and metal-air batteries that operate in basic media have the potential to exhibit better cost-effective performance than proton exchange membrane fuel cells, which operate in acidic environments. Given that oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) kinetics can be significantly enhanced in alkaline environments, platinum-group-metal (PGM)-free cathode electrocatalysts can be employed to enhance the activity and stability of catalysts, and applying these catalysts at the cathode side of an alkaline fuel cell is advantageous [1–4]. PGM-free catalysts demonstrate an ORR activity performance that is on par with or even better than that of commercial Pt/C catalysts but also typically with higher long-term stability. Among the promising PGM-free catalysts, metal–nitrogen–carbon catalysts (M−N−C), [5–7] where M denotes transition metals (often Fe or Co), are potential candidates for driving ORR through the direct 4e− pathway. These catalysts can be easily prepared via high-temperature pyrolysis of inexpensive precursors and show high ORR activities when tested for a rotating disk electrode (RDE) [8-10]. However, alkaline fuel cell performance using these materials has rarely been demonstrated to be better than the performance of commercial Pt/C catalysts in contact with polymer electrolytes [11–14]. M−N−C catalysts are always associated with low volume density of metal–nitrogen active sites, which require thick catalyst layers (up to 100 μm) to reach the loading required by the high oxygen reduction activity and consequently reduce the cathode performance. Therefore, other PGM-free electrocatalysts with high volumetric activity [11] must be developed to enable alkaline fuel cells. Silver metal is precious but abundant and relatively inexpensive compared with nitrogen-doped graphene. When the non-PGM catalyst is silver metal, the thickness of the catalyst layer is not significantly different from the thickness (about 10 μm) of a catalyst layer based on Pt. Consequently, the transport losses in a Ag-catalysed air cathode should not be significantly higher than the transport losses in a Pt-catalysed air cathode. Given their relatively low price and high long-term stability in alkaline conditions, Ag-based catalysts have promoted the development of fuel cells, and the ability to use non-PGM catalysts, such as Ag-Cu [15–20] and Ag-Sn [21,22], in alkaline fuel cells and zinc-air batteries have been well documented in our previous work. AgCo [23] electrocatalysts exhibit higher specific activity and long-term stability than those of commercial Pt/C, and the ORR mechanisms of these non-PGM silver electrocatalysts in alkaline media have also been studied [24–26]. As a kind of impurity-doped alloy, dilute nanoalloys that dope few precious metals to common elements, such as single-atom alloys [27,28] and single-atomic-site catalysts [29,30], have attracted the attention of researchers, dilute nanoalloys could provide ultralow metal loading for alkaline fuel cells and metal-air batteries [31–35]. Several dilute alloy catalysts exhibit the electronic structures of the low-content precious metal element and unprecedented catalytic properties [36–38]. Greiner et al. [39] reported that in a AgCu single-atom alloy, the Cu 3d states are five times narrower than those of bulk Cu (that is, 0.5 eV for Cu in AgCu single-atom alloy compared with 2.5 eV for bulk Cu), and the Cu–H bond in AgCu is significantly stronger than that in bulk Cu. Wrasman et al. [40] reported that AuPd single-atom alloys can be synthesised experimentally, thereby improving the hydro-oxidation performance of 2-propanol to acetone. Nigam et al. [41] reported that a novel AgPt9 single-atom alloy at the sub-nanometer length scale shows superior catalytic behaviour for SO3 decomposition. However, no work has designed an optimal dilute alloy catalyst for ORR. Inspired by the traditional single-atom alloys, several studies have investigated the effect of a few impurities on the structure and catalytic properties of Ag-based nanoalloys. One of the major results of such catalysis research is the identification of the optimal element in the silver matrix that leads to the highest activity for alkaline fuel cells. In this study, the catalytic performance of a series of M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys, where M is a 3d transition metal atom (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn), is investigated as ORR catalysts in alkaline media with density functional theory calculations and experiments. The M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy catalysts exhibit higher stability when the M atom is doped on the subsurface (2L) of the Ag(1 1 1) facet than when the M atom is doped on the surface (1L) of Ag(1 1 1). For the first time, the Ag-based dilute nanoalloy is determined to exhibit subsurface stability, which is related to the positive charge transfer of surface Ag atoms to the surrounding atoms. A new ternary Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy with higher activity than Cu1Ag(1 1 1) or Mn1Ag(1 1 1) is designed with DFT then prepared experimentally using the pulse laser deposition (PLD) method for the first time. The resultant CuMnAg and dealloyed DE-CuMnAg ternary alloys exhibit an enhanced catalytic activity compared with pure Ag and CuAg catalysts. These newfound CuMnAg nanoalloys are promising cathode catalysts for alkaline fuel cell and metal-air applications. 2 Computational and experimental method Computational model: The periodic Ag(1 1 1) surface is modelled using a slab model with a 2 × 2 supercell of four atomic layers as shown in Fig. 1 a. Single atoms from all ten elements in the 3d transition metals M were doped into the Ag(1 1 1) surface (1L), subsurface (2L) or bulk (3L). For the (2x2) model, the surface M atom density is 0 for the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy and 12.5% if we assume subsurface M atom is doped in the surface and subsurface layer, which are still in the dilute alloy regime (~10%). In the surface optimization calculations, the top two layers of adsorbates were relaxed and three bottom layers were fixed to reflect bulk positions. A 15 Å vacuum space above the surface was created to separate the surface slab and its periodic image. Spin-polarized DFT calculations are done for systems with oxygen molecule adsorbed. DFT calculations: Density functional theory calculations were performed on the electrocatalytic reactions of oxygen reduction reaction through the Dmol3 package included in the software, Materials Studio. [42] All the calculations were carried out using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) exchange–correlation functional proposed by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE). [43] The van der Waals force was explicitly included using the DFT-TS method to adopt for dispersion corrections [26]. Double numerical plus polarization (DNP) [44] was used as the basis set, while the ion–electron interaction was described using the all-electron-relativistic-core method. The orbital cutoff range of 5.0 Å and a Fermi smearing of 0.003 Ha (1 Ha = 27.212 eV) was used. A set of 7 × 7 × 1 Monkhorst Pack k-point meshes are used to perform the Brillouin Zone calculations. The convergence criteria for the SCF (self-consistent field) convergence, energy, maximum force and maximum displacement during optimization are taken as 1.0 × 10-6, 1.0 × 10-5 Ha, 0.002 Ha Å−1 and 0.005 Å, respectively. The conductor-like screening model (COSMO) is used to simulate an H2O solvent environment throughout the whole process [45–47]. For the intermediates, the adsorption energies (E ads) of are calculated using the formula: E ads = E tot – (E surface + E S), where E tot, E surface and E S are the energy of the M1Ag(1 1 1) surface with adsorbate species, the clean M1Ag(1 1 1) surface and isolated adsorbate species, respectively. While a negative value is meaning that the exothermic adsorption. Based on former researcher's works, the four-electron ORR mechanisms were investigated on the Ag(1 1 1) and Ag3Cu(1 1 1) [25]. The ORR overpotential is calculated using the theoretical models of the alkaline solution, and the overall ORR processes of O2 is reduced to OH− through the path of O2(g) + 2H2O(l) + 4e− → 4OH−, where the elementary reaction steps on the catalytic surface are in the following reaction paths (1) ~ (4): O2(g) + 2H2O(l) + 4e-+*→+OOH*+OH–+H2O(l) + 3e- (1) OOH*+OH_+H2O(l) + 3e-→O*+2OH–+H2O(l) + 2e- (2) O*+2OH–+H2O(l) + 2e-→OH*+3OH_+e- (3) OH*+3OH_+e-→4OH- (4) The free energy diagram of adsorbed intermediates was calculated according to the method proposed by Nøskov et al. [48] On this basis, the working potential of the fuel cell can be extrapolated. In detail, the free energy change (ΔG) is calculated as ΔG = ΔE + ΔZPE − TΔS + ΔGU + ΔGpH, where ΔE is the electronic energy obtained from DFT, ΔZPE is the zero-point energy correction, T is the standard temperature (298.15 K), and ΔS is the change of entropy, respectively. ΔGU = eU, where U is the electrode potential, and e is the transferred charge. ΔGpH = − kBT × ln10 × pH is the correction of the H+ concentration free energy, where kB is the Boltzmann constant, and pH assumed to be thirteen for an alkaline solution. Preparation of Ag-based catalyst: Pure Ag, CuAg and CuMnAg catalyst were synthesized on a glassy carbon electrode by using pulsed laser deposition (PLD). Several Ag-based alloy targets have been fabricated by vacuum arc melting method. The targets were irradiated using a nanosecond Q-switched Nd:YAG laser (EKSPLA, Lithuania) with a wavelength of 266 nm pulse duration of 3–6 ns, beam diameter of 1 mm, and energy density of 200 mJ/pulse. The distance between substrate and target was set to 3.5 cm during the process of deposition. The deposition time is 1 h and the loading amount of Ag is 3.6 μg. Electrochemical characterization: Electrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI660C electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument, Shanghai). A classic three-electrode cell was used in this study, which contains a Hg/HgO, Pt, and the glassy carbon electrode (GCE) supports catalyst as the reference, counter, and working electrode. The ORR measurements were performed in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solutions with using the rotation disk electrode and a sweep rate of 10 mV/s. The current densities of ORR polarization were normalized in reference to the geometric area of GCE (0.196 cm2). All potentials are reported relative to the RHE (VRHE = VNHE + 0.0591pH). All the solutions were prepared by deionized water (18 MΩ cm). The electrochemical surface area of dealloyed Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 was measured by the Pb-stripping voltammetry. Pb-stripping voltammetry was performed in 0.1 M KOH + 125 μM Pb(NO3)2 solution with N2-purged solution. The CV curves of the commercial Pt/C catalyst was measured in N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stability of the M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy structure with M atom at the surface (1L) or subsurface (2L) site To confirm the stability of the M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy structure with the M atom at the surface (1L) or subsurface (2L) site, we compared the segregation and mixing energies. The segregation behaviour of the surface atoms was calculated using segregation energy E seg, which can be defined as the energy difference between the doped atoms on the surface and inside. Surface segregation energy can be calculated as (5) E seg = E M 1 Ag 111 1L/2L - E M 1 Ag 111 3L where EM1Ag(1 1 1)1L/2L, and EM1Ag(1 1 1)3L represent the total energy of the M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy with the M doped on the surface or first layer (1L) or on the subsurface or second layer (2L) and in the bulk phase or third layer (3L) of the Ag(1 1 1) alloy system. A negative E seg means that the doped single atom tends to locate on the surface (1L) and subsurface (2L). M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys with M atoms at 1L, 2L or 3L sites are denoted as 1L-M1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) or 3L-M1Ag(1 1 1) hereafter. Table 1 shows that the E seg values of all 10 1L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are positive, indicating that 1L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are unstable and different from the well-established notion of a single-atom alloy where the doping atom is supposed to be on the topmost surface layer. Fig. 1a further compares the total energy of the 1L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) and 3L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) alloy systems. Compared with the pure Ag(1 1 1) surface, the 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) alloy exhibits the lowest total energy of − 0.571 eV among all three alloy systems, indicating that the 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) alloy is the most stable structure in the Cu1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy system. To consider the gas environmental effect, we compared the total energy of the 1L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) configuration under adsorbed atomic hydrogen in Fig. S1. The results indicate that in the presence of adsorbed hydrogen, the 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) subsurface structure is also thermodynamically stable, similar to the stability of 2L-Cu1Ag alloys in a vacuum environment. It is should be noted that the presence of oxygen species OH and reactant O2 during ORR reaction in the alkaline environment will affect the stability of the 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) surface, and these adsorbates would induce the surface segregation of Cu atoms at a higher experimental temperature [49,50]. This subsurface segregation tendency of a single Cu atom on the Ag(1 1 1) surface was further checked on all 3d transition metals. Table 1 and Fig. 1b present the calculated segregation energies of 3d transition metals on the M1Ag(1 1 1) surface. Compared with all positive E seg values of the 10 1L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys, the E seg values of seven 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are negative, except for Ti, V and Cr, indicating that the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys with M = Sc, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn follow this subsurface segregation tendency. Notably, the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are more thermodynamically stable catalysts than the 1L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys with M = Sc, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn. The binding strength of Ag and the alloying atom M in 1L- or 2L- M1Ag(1 1 1) systems was further calculated by means of mixing energy, which is calculated as (6) E mix = [ x E ( M x - y A g y ) - y ( E A g x ) - ( x - y ) E ( M x )]/ x 2 where E(Mx-yAgy) is the total energy of the Mx-yAgy surface. E(Agx) and E(Mx) are the energies of the respective monometallic surfaces with the same structure as the Mx-yAgy surface. The definition indicates that a negative value corresponds to an attractive interaction between solute atoms. Table 1 lists the mixing energies for the 10 3d transition atom elements and reveals that all values of E mix for the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are more negative or lower than those for the 1L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys. As shown in Fig. 1c, the values of E mix for the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are negative, except for M = Ti, V and Cr, indicating that 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are more stable than 1L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys with M = Sc, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn. As a rule, the phase stability tendency towards an alloy can be understood through energy factors, such as surface segregation energy and mixing energy. That is, a large and positive surface segregation energy means the structure of the alloy is unstable at the surface, and large and positive mixing energy may affect the repulsive interaction between the solute and solvent atoms. Thus, 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are more stable structures because these subsurface dilute nanoalloys have low surface segregation and mixing energies when the Ag(1 1 1) surface is doped with these 3d transition metal elements (i.e. Sc, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn). These theoretical predictions are consistent with previous experimental results. Bocquet [51] conducted ultra-high vacuum experiments on copper film growth at the Ag(1 1 1) surface and found that copper forms islands enclosed by a single layer of Ag at room temperature, i.e. a Cu@Ag core–shell structure, which is consistent with the DFT results in this study. Holewinski[23] explored Ag–Co alloy nanoparticles for oxygen reduction and adopted a model in which the outermost layer of the alloy is occupied by silver atoms, similar to the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys in this study. Further atomic charge analysis was performed to explain these subsurface stabilities in terms of an electronic factor. Fig. 1d presents the Mulliken charge of an alloying M atom on the surface (1L) and subsurface (2L) of M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy. The atomic charge number of the M atom decreases with an increasing atomic number from Sc to Cu, and the Sc element exhibits the maximum Mulliken charge. Among these 3d transition metal atoms, Fig. 1d shows that the atomic charge number of the Co and Cu alloying element in the 2L site is larger than that in the 1L site, which corresponds to the negative segregation energy and mixing energy in the 2L site than that in the 1L site in Fig. 1b and 1c, thus, the atomic charge number is proportional to the stability of the Co and Cu atoms in Ag(1 1 1) alloy, indicating the positive correlation between atomic charge number and alloy formation energy [52] Nevertheless, despite the Mulliken charge of alloying elements in Ti1Ag(1 1 1) and Cr1Ag(1 1 1) alloys in the 2L configuration are also larger than that in the 1L configuration, they do not correspond the stable segregation energy and mixing energy in the 2L configuration in Fig. 1b and 1c. That is to say, the higher Mulliken charge of alloying elements is not correlated to the easy formation of Ti1Ag(1 1 1) and Cr1Ag(1 1 1) alloys. There is no significant relationship between charge transfer and alloy mixing energy, that is, it is different from previous papers. In general, the higher the Mulliken charge in 2L-Ti1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Cr1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Co1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) the more stable the structure of the alloying element is, but stability cannot be determined entirely by charge transfer. Fig. 1e presents the Mulliken charge of the surface Ag atom in 1L- and 2L- M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys. Compared with the Mulliken charge (-0.029) of surface Ag atoms on pure Ag(1 1 1) surface, the atomic charge of the surface Ag atom in 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys is larger than that of pure Ag(1 1 1), whereas the atomic charge of the surface Ag atom in 1L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys is smaller than that of pure Ag(1 1 1), except for the Cu element. This result indicates that the charge transfer in 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys is from the surface Ag atoms to the atoms underneath. The relative positive atomic charge of the surface Ag atoms contributes to alloy stability in the subsurface 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy, except for M = Ti, V and Cr. The Hume–Rothery rules [53–55] can further rationalize the formation of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy. Firstly, considering the electronegativity difference in the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy which is less than 0.4, except for that of Ag and Sc elements, the positive atomic transfer of surface Ag atoms is the direct evidence of charge transfer from surface Ag to M. Thus, a single alloying atom has an anionic nature, the surface Ag atom has a cationic nature and the resulting Coulomb attraction stabilises the dilute nanoalloy. Secondly, considering the atomic radii in the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy, the difference between the atomic radius of Ag and M is less than 15%, indicating that most of the M elements are dissolved in Ag and form solid solutions through the Hume–Rothery rule. However, the atomic radius of Ag is 0.165 nm, which is larger than those of most late 3d transition metal elements (e.g. Mn, Fe, Co and Cu). Therefore, the surface Ag atom releases a lattice strain and stabilises the dilute nanoalloy structure. The subsurface stability of alloy is attributed to the positive charge transfer and the lattice strain effect of surface Ag atoms. 3.2 Electronic structure of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys The electronic structure of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys has been intensely investigated because these nanoalloys exhibit high structural stability. Figs. 2 and S2 show the calculated d orbital partial density of state (PDOS) of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy, M(1 1 1) and Ag(1 1 1) surface and the d electron orbital of single M atom in the 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1). Fig. 2 a shows that the 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy exhibits a d band characteristic bandwidth that ranges from − 1.0 eV to − 6.0 eV, which is almost unchanged compared with the pure Ag(1 1 1) surface except for a small sharp peak from − 1.5 eV to − 2.5 eV, as shown in Fig. 2b. The sharp peak is the d electron orbital of the single Cu atom in 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1). This Cu 3d in 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) is extremely narrow, approximately symmetrical in linear shape and one-fifth the bandwidth of the d band in bulk Cu(1 1 1), indicating the absence of strong hybridisation between Cu 3d state and their coordination environment, it is called a free-atom-like electronic structures in previous single atom alloy studies [39]. As shown in Fig. 2c–2f, similar free-atom-like electronic structures are also observed in other 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys, such as Ni1Ag(1 1 1) and Zn1Ag(1 1 1); that is, single Ni and Zn atoms also exhibit such strong d band narrowing compared with the bulk Ni(1 1 1) and Zn(1 1 1) surfaces. This study clearly shows that 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Ni1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Zn1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit a free-atom-like electronic structure previously unique to single atom alloys, although these 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys are completely different from the well-established notion of single-atom alloys where the doping atom tends to segregate in the topmost surface layer [39]. By contrast, as shown in Fig. 2g, 2 h and S2, 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and other 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys behave differently. The d band centre (ε d) is an important indicator of the ORR activities of nanoalloy catalysts with a rather simple rule: the higher in energy the d-states are relative to the Fermi energy of the metal, the stronger the interaction with the adsorbate states will be [56,57]. As listed in Table 2 , the ε d were calculated for this 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1). For example, the 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) possesses a ε d value of −3.949 eV, which is higher than that of pure Ag(1 1 1) with ε d = − 4.074 eV. As shown in Figs. 2e and S2, except that of 2L-Zn1Ag(1 1 1), all 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) nanoalloys exhibit a similarly higher ε d than that of pure Ag(1 1 1). The calculated adsorption energies of the O and OOH reactive intermediates on the surface of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys are also higher than that of pure Ag(1 1 1). Compared with pure Ag(1 1 1) with ε d value of − 4.074 eV, 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) exhibit relatively higher ε d values (−3.923 and − 3.949 eV, respectively) and relatively higher O2 adsorption energies (−0.664 and − 0.691 eV, respectively) than that of Ag(1 1 1), indicating that the catalytic activities for 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) are agreeable with the trend predicted from the ε d. However, as listed in Table 2, other 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloys exhibit a much higher ε d than pure Ag(1 1 1) but a much lower O2 adsorption energy than pure Ag(1 1 1). For example, 2L-Ti1Ag(1 1 1) possesses a similar ε d of − 3.942 eV but ultralow O2 adsorption energy of − 0.229 eV. As shown in Fig. 2b, the d electron orbital of the single Cu atom in 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) is extremely narrow, and this narrowing of the strong d band increases the strength between the metal and O2 interaction, and thus increases the adsorption energy for Cu1Ag(1 1 1). This narrowing of the d band is related to the poor mixing between the d states of each metal in the alloy caused by the overlapping of wave functions in space and energy because no energy overlap exists between the 3d state of Cu and the 4d band of Ag. The energy mismatch between Ag 4d and Cu 3d states is the main reason for the sharpness and degeneracy of Cu 3d states [39]. The higher O2 adsorption energy on 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) may be related to the narrowing of the d band, thus reducing the influence of the ε d on the adsorption energy of the reaction reactant. 3.3 Free energy diagram of the oxygen reduction process in 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) catalysts Two major types of mechanisms towards ORR exist: the 4-electron (4e) transfer mechanism with the final production of H2O and the 2-electron (2e) transfer mechanism featuring the production of H2O2. The 4e transfer mechanism has been demonstrated theoretically and experimentally for ORR on Ag-based nanoalloy [24–26]. Zhang et al. predicted from first-principles calculations that the overpotentials of pure Ag and core–shell Ag/Ag3Cu alloys are 0.493 and 0.469, respectively, which are comparable to that of Pt(1 1 1) facets [48]. Free energy diagrams of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) for ORR are plotted in Figs. 3 and S3 as estimated from Eqs. (3)–(6) in alkaline medium and reveal that the performance of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) catalysts is limited by the reduction of O2 to form OOH. That is, the reduction of O2 to form OOH is the activity-determining step, which is the same as that of the Ag(1 1 1) surface [25]. In particular, the working potential values of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) with M = Cu, Ni, Zn and Mn are − 0.007, −0.025, 0.441 and 0.002 V, respectively, and the corresponding overpotential values are 0.468, 0.486, 0.902 and 0.459 V, respectively. On the basis of the overpotential of Ag(1 1 1) of 0.493 V, 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) (M = Cu, Ni and Mn) clearly improves the ORR catalytic activity, whereas 2L-Zn1Ag(1 1 1) decreases the ORR catalytic activity. In spite of Cu1Ag(1 1 1), Ni1Ag(1 1 1) and Zn1Ag(1 1 1) with free-atom-like d states, only Cu1Ag(1 1 1) shows an appropriate O adsorption energy (−3.702 eV) and appropriate d-band center (−3.949 eV). Ni1Ag(1 1 1) has stronger O adsorption energy (−3.804 eV) and its ε d value is closer to Fermi level (−3.900 eV) than Cu1Ag(1 1 1). Zn1Ag(1 1 1) has weaker O adsorption energy (−3.660 eV) and its ε d is farther away from Fermi energy level (−4.303 eV) than Cu1Ag(1 1 1). Therefore, the catalytic performance of Cu1Ag(1 1 1) is benefited from its optimized O adsorption energy and ε d. As shown in Fig. S3, 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys with M = Sc, Ti and V exhibit a lower ORR performance than Ag(1 1 1), and their free energy diagrams are similar to that of the Pt(1 1 1) surface, that is, the OH− desorption step shows a high barrier during the multi-electron transfer step of ORR processing. 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys with M = Fe and Co exhibit a higher ORR performance than Ag(1 1 1), and 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys with M = Cr exhibit a lower ORR performance than Ag(1 1 1), and their free energy diagram illustrates that their catalytic performance is limited by the reduction of O2 to form OOH, which is the same with the Ag(1 1 1) surface. Thus, it is the adsorption step of O2 and not the OH− desorption step that is important for 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) catalysts because it affects the formation of OOH in the next step when the Ag(1 1 1) surface is doped with these interesting transition metal elements (Cu, Ni, Mn, Cr, Fe and Co). The strongly adsorbed O2 intermediates on the Ag(1 1 1) surface accelerate the rate-limiting step and activation of the M1Ag(1 1 1) catalysts when doped by Mn and Cu atom. To theoretically evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) catalysts, the overpotentials were plotted as a function of the adsorption energies of relevant O, OH, O2 and OOH intermediates as shown in Fig. S4. Fig. S4c indicates a linear relationship between the overpotentials and O2 adsorption energies and suggests that the ORR catalytic activity originates from the stronger O2 adsorption on 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1). Moreover, alloying Ag(1 1 1) with Mn and Cu metals can enhance the adsorption ability of O2 on Ag-based alloy. Fig. S5 shows the ORR overpotentials against the ε d on 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) and reveals that the extremely high ε d value in Zn1Ag(1 1 1) and extremely small ε d value in V1Ag(1 1 1) do not benefit the catalytic performance. The moderate ε d value in Mn1Ag(1 1 1) exhibits the best catalytic performance. Although the relationship between the overpotentials and adsorption energies of intermediates can provide a qualitative argument for tuning the catalytic activity, predicting the catalytic activity with the intrinsic properties of materials is preferred to guide the discovery of new catalysts. In this regard, we relate the overpotentials to the atomic radius, surface strain, electronegativity, and Mulliken charge of alloys from the perspective of strain and ligand effects [58–60]. Fig. S6 discusses these effects in detail. We surmised that several changes in the electrocatalytic performance of the surface may be regarded as primarily due to the ligand effect from the interactions with the subsurface metal atoms and not to the surface strain. Kitchin and Nørskov [59] studied the electronic properties of Pt(1 1 1) surfaces, where the second layer of metal atoms has been replaced by one of the 3d transition metals. They found that the change in surface electronic or chemical properties may be attributed mainly to the ligand effect and not to surface strain [59]. 3.4 Design of CuMnAg ternary alloy and experimental results On the basis of our prediction from the free energy diagram, the overpotentials of 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) are 0.459 and 0.468 V, respectively. They exhibit an improvement in ORR catalytic activity compared with the overpotentials of Ag(1 1 1) at 0.493 V but still lag behind that of the Pt(1 1 1) surface with an overpotential of 0.441 V. We designed a new ternary Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy with DFT to obtain increased ORR activity. The structure of most favorable adsorption sites for Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) ternary material as shown in Fig. S7. Fig. 4 a shows the free-energy diagrams of 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) for ORR at different electrode potentials. It illustrates that the performance of electrocatalysts is limited by the reduction of O2 to OOH, that is, the reduction of O2 to form OOH is the activity-determining step, similar to that for the Ag(1 1 1) surface. Fig. 4b and Table 2 show the ORR overpotential after the third Mn element was introduced. The overpotential of 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) is 0.450 V compared with the Pt(1 1 1) surface’s overpotentials of 0.441 V, indicating that the co-doping of Cu and Mn is beneficial for the Ag(1 1 1) surface. Fig. 4c shows the PDOS of 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1). As shown in Table 2, the ε d of Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) is − 3.817 eV, which is closer to the Fermi energy level than that of the 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1). Fig. 4d indicates that 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) also exhibits the narrowing of the strong d-band due to the introduction of the Cu element, which is similar to that of 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1). Table 2 shows that the adsorption energy of O2 on 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) is − 0.821 eV, which is higher than that of Cu1Ag(1 1 1) (i.e. − 0.664 eV). The adsorption energy of OH on 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) is − 2.293 eV, which is slightly smaller than that on 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) (−2.339 eV). Therefore, the strong adsorption of O2 and weak adsorption of OH on 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) may result in reduced overpotentials, which are beneficial to catalytic performance. Uniformly distributed nanoparticles of pure Ag, CuAg and CuMnAg catalysts were prepared using the pulse laser deposition method. In order to compare the catalytic activity of the leaching the segregated transition metals away of Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalysts, the DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 alloys were prepared by the pulse laser deposition (PLD) technology and were dealloyed using a selective leaching process. The selective leaching procedure was carried out in N2-saturated 0.5 M HCL solution. Fig. 5 a shows that the HRTEM image of the Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 electrocatalyst, which has a size of 3–6 nm and is uniformly distributed on the substrate. The lattice planes of 0.233 nm are attributed to the Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 solid solution phase. The corresponding SAED pattern in Fig. 5b verifies the polycrystalline structure of the Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 nanoalloy. The EDS in Fig. 5c indicates that the atomic ratio of Ag: Cu: Mn is approximately 74.85: 16.69: 8.46, indicating that each surface dopant atom’s density is too low and remains in the dilute alloy regime. Fig. 5d shows that the elemental mapping reveals that the Ag, Cu and Mn elements are evenly distributed across all the nanoalloys and demonstrates that the Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 was an alloy phase composed of Cu, Mn and Ag element. After the dealloying process, the TEM images (Fig. 6 a) clearly show that DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 with an average particle size of approximately 2–8 nm. HRTEM examination showed the lattice spacings of 0.233 nm were indexed as the (1 1 1) planes. The SAED in Fig. 6b observes the well-defined polycrystalline rings. The atomic ratio of Ag: Cu: Mn in the catalyst was determined to be 80.49: 12.83: 6.68 by EDS (Fig. 6c). This result signifies that partial Cu and Mn atoms dissolved after the dealloying treatment. As shown in Fig. 6d, Ag, Cu and Mn elements are evenly distributed across all the nanoalloys, which confirmed the formation of the CuMnAg alloy. To check if the ORR performance of the Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 nanoalloy catalyst is enhanced, the catalytic activities of pure Ag, Cu25Ag75, Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75, DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and Pt/C catalysts were systematically characterized by RDE electrochemical measurement in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. Fig. 7 a,c shows the rotation-rate-dependent ORR polarization curves of the Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalysts and their Koutecky-Levich plots (Fig. 7b,d). The number of electron transfer (n) of the CuMnAg catalyst is about 4 during the ORR process at the potentials range between 0.2 and 0.5 VRHE, suggesting that ORR is catalysed by the efficient 4e- pathway on the surface of the CuMnAg catalyst, i.e. O2 + 2H2O + 4e- = 4OH-, which is consistent with the theoretical results of the previous calculation. The half-wave potential (E1/2) or overpotential is an important parameter for evaluating the ORR activity of the electrocatalyst and is measured by the ORR polarization curves in Fig. 8 a. It shows that the half-wave potentials (E1/2) of pure Ag, Cu25Ag75, Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalysts was 0.63, 0.69, 0.73 and 0.76 V (versus RHE), respectively. Clearly, the catalytic activity of DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 is close to that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst (0.84 V versus RHE). Moreover, the dealloyed DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalyst possesses a higher ORR activity the un-dealloyed initial Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalyst. Ternary Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalysts exhibit an overpotential of 0.50 and 0.47 V, which is close to the predicted overpotential of 0.450 V, and highlight the promising potential of CuMnAg cathode catalysts for alkaline fuel cell and metal-air applications. The specific activities at 0.8 VRHE of Ag, Cu25Ag75, Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75, DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and Pt/C catalysts were calculated by normalized the kinetic currents to the ECSA and the loading amount of Pt or Ag in these catalysts, respectively. As seen in Fig. 8b, the specific activity of DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 catalyst is 0.146 mA cm−2, which is about 82% relative to that of Pt/C (0.178 mA cm−2). The specific activity of Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 (0.121 mA cm−2) catalyst is about 68% compared to that of Pt/C catalyst. To gain more insights into the reaction kinetics for the ORR, the Tafel plots were shown in Fig. 8c. As shown in Fig. 8c, the Tafel slope increased in the following order: DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 (62.55 mV decade−1) < Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 (66.94 mV decade−1) < Pt/C (70.53 mV decade−1) < Cu25Ag75 (72.48 mV decade−1) < Ag (80.37 mV decade−1). Compared with Tafel slope of Cu25Ag75 (72.48 mV decade−1), the slope of Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 decreased by 5.54 mV decade−1, which proved that the addition of Mn accelerated the reaction rate of Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 in the kinetic current region, making the Tafel slope decreased. Here, the DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 exhibits smallest Tafel slope and is therefore the most efficient ORR catalyst among all the catalysts in this study, suggesting an outstanding intrinsic ORR kinetics of DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 alloy. This result is in concomitant with the orders of specific activity. Meanwhile, the better ORR catalytic activity of DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 alloy compared to Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 alloy catalysts demonstrated that the roughness of surface (exposed surface atoms) plays an important role in determining the ORR pathway. The lower Tafel slopes than Pt/C catalyst suggest that DE-Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 and Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 exhibit remarkable catalytic activity in alkaline media. Although Cu12.5Mn12.5Ag75 is still slightly lower than Pt/C in potential, it has the potential to replace Pt/C due to its low manufacturing cost and activity close to Pt/C. So, the CuMnAg catalyst is a promising candidate to substitute the Pt/C catalyst applied in the commercialization of alkaline fuel cells and metal-air batteries. 4 Conclusions In this work, we investigated the thermodynamic stability of dilute nanoalloy catalysts to guide theoretical ORR catalysts of dilute nanoalloys by considering M1Ag(1 1 1) as a case study. M1Ag(1 1 1) is a 3d transition metal atom M (M = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) doped on the surface and subsurface of Ag(1 1 1). We compared the surface segregation and mixing energies of M1Ag(1 1 1) and found that the M doped on the subsurface (2L) is more stable than doped on the surface (1L) of Ag(1 1 1). The subsurface stability is caused by the relative positive charge transfer of surface Ag atoms through atomic charge analysis. This investigation is important for further studies on the electronic structure and ORR activities of 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1). Furthermore, 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Ni1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Zn1Ag(1 1 1) are dilute nanoalloys with free-atom-like d states. Meanwhile, 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) have the most catalytic activity with overpotentials of 0.459 and 0.468 V, respectively, among all 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) alloy systems. With theoretical guidance, a ternary 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloy was reasonably designed for the first time in this work. This ternary nanoalloy exhibits higher activity than 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) catalysts and a more suitable ε d. On the basis of the theoretical prediction, a CuMnAg ternary catalyst was fabricated with the pulsed laser deposition method. The ternary catalyst exhibits an overpotential of 0.50 and 0.47 V, which is close to the predicted overpotential of 0.450 V. This research offers a basis for promising applications and potentials of the CuMnAg ternary catalyst in alkaline fuel cell and metal-air systems. coredata.dc:description: To address the sluggish kinetics of the electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), we consider a family of silver-based dilute nanoalloys by alloying the Ag(1 1 1) with one 3d transition metal atom M (M = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) as ORR catalysts in alkaline media. The M1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit higher stability when M is on the subsurface (2L-M1Ag(1 1 1)) than when M is on the surface (1L-M1Ag(1 1 1)) of the Ag(1 1 1) facet as observed from surface segregation and mixing energies, and this subsurface stability is attributed to the relative positive charge transfer of surface Ag atoms as revealed from atomic charge analysis. Thus, 2L-M1Ag(1 1 1) catalysts are further investigated for their electronic structure and ORR activities. Particularly, 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1), 2L-Ni1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Zn1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit a free-atom-like d state, and 2L-Mn1Ag(1 1 1) and 2L-Cu1Ag(1 1 1) dilute nanoalloys exhibit an ORR overpotential of 0.459 and 0.468 V, respectively. For the first time, the ternary 2L-Cu1Mn1Ag(1 1 1) is theoretically predicted with an overpotential of 0.450 V. Motivated by this prediction, we prepare a ternary CuMnAg nanoalloy by using the pulse laser deposition method. These ternary CuMnAg and dealloyed DE-CuMnAg catalysts exhibit an ORR overpotential of 0.50 and 0.47 V that is close to the predicted overpotential and that of a commercial Pt/C catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Alloying effect in silver-based dilute nanoalloy catalysts for oxygen reduction reactions
